verses.text: Now Jehoshaphat had riches and honour in abundance, and joined affinity with Ahab.

And after \add certain\add* years he went down to Ahab to Samaria. And Ahab killed sheep and oxen for him in abundance, and for the people that \add he had\add* with him, and persuaded him to go up \add with him\add* to Ramoth-gilead.

And Ahab king of Israel said unto Jehoshaphat king of Judah, Wilt thou go with me \add to\add* Ramoth-gilead? And he answered him, I \add am\add* as thou \add art\add*, and my people as thy people; and \add we will be\add* with thee in the war.
And Jehoshaphat said unto the king of Israel, Inquire, I pray thee, at the word of the \sc Lord\sc* to day.

Therefore the king of Israel gathered together \add of\add* prophets four hundred men, and said unto them, Shall we go to Ramoth-gilead to battle, or shall I forbear? And they said, Go up; for God will deliver \add it\add* into the king’s hand.
But Jehoshaphat said, \add Is there\add* not here a prophet of the \sc Lord\sc* besides, that we might inquire of him?

And the king of Israel said unto Jehoshaphat, \add There is\add* yet one man, by whom \add we\add* may inquire of the \sc Lord\sc*: but I hate him; for he never prophesied good unto me, but always evil: the same \add is\add* Micaiah the son of Imla. And Jehoshaphat said, Let not the king say so.
And the king of Israel called for one \add of his\add* officers, and said, Fetch quickly Micaiah the son of Imla.

And the king of Israel and Jehoshaphat king of Judah sat either of them on his throne, clothed in \add their\add* robes, and they sat in a void place \add at\add* the entering in of the gate of Samaria; and all the prophets prophesied before them.
And Zedekiah the son of Chenaanah had made him horns of iron, and said, Thus saith the \sc Lord\sc*, With these thou shalt push Syria until they be consumed.
And all the prophets prophesied so, saying, Go up \add to\add* Ramoth-gilead, and prosper: for the \sc Lord\sc* shall deliver \add it\add* into the hand of the king.

And the messenger that went to call Micaiah spake to him, saying, Behold, the words of the prophets \add declare\add* good to the king with one assent; let thy word therefore, I pray thee, be like one of theirs, and speak thou good.
And Micaiah said, \add As\add* the \sc Lord\sc* liveth, even what my God saith, that will I speak.

And when he was come to the king, the king said unto him, Micaiah, shall we go to Ramoth-gilead to battle, or shall I forbear? And he said, Go ye up, and prosper, and they shall be delivered into your hand.
And the king said to him, How many times shall I adjure thee that thou say nothing but the truth to me in the name of the \sc Lord\sc*?

Then he said, I did see all Israel scattered upon the mountains, as sheep that have no shepherd: and the \sc Lord\sc* said, These have no master; let them return \add therefore\add* every man to his house in peace.
And the king of Israel said to Jehoshaphat, Did I not tell thee \add that\add* he would not prophesy good unto me, but evil?
Again he said, Therefore hear the word of the \sc Lord\sc*; I saw the \sc Lord\sc* sitting upon his throne, and all the host of heaven standing on his right hand and \add on\add* his left.
And the \sc Lord\sc* said, Who shall entice Ahab king of Israel, that he may go up and fall at Ramoth-gilead? And one spake saying after this manner, and another saying after that manner.
Then there came out a spirit, and stood before the \sc Lord\sc*, and said, I will entice him. And the \sc Lord\sc* said unto him, Wherewith?

And he said, I will go out, and be a lying spirit in the mouth of all his prophets. And \add the \+sc Lord\+sc*\add* said, Thou shalt entice \add him\add*, and thou shalt also prevail: go out, and do \add even\add* so.
Now therefore behold, the \sc Lord\sc* hath put a lying spirit in the mouth of these thy prophets, and the \sc Lord\sc* hath spoken evil against thee.
Then Zedekiah the son of Chenaanah came near, and smote Micaiah upon the cheek, and said, Which way went the spirit of the \sc Lord\sc* from me to speak unto thee?
And Micaiah said, Behold, thou shalt see on that day when thou shalt go into an inner chamber to hide thyself.
Then the king of Israel said, Take ye Micaiah, and carry him back to Amon the governor of the city, and to Joash the king’s son;
and say, Thus saith the king, Put this \add fellow in\add* the prison, and feed him with bread of affliction and with water of affliction, until I return in peace.
And Micaiah said, If thou certainly return in peace, \add then\add* hath not the \sc Lord\sc* spoken by me. And he said, Hearken, all ye people.
So the king of Israel and Jehoshaphat the king of Judah went up to Ramoth-gilead.
And the king of Israel said unto Jehoshaphat, I will disguise myself, and will go to the battle; but put thou on thy robes. So the king of Israel disguised himself; and they went to the battle.
Now the king of Syria had commanded the captains of the chariots that \add were\add* with him, saying, Fight ye not with small or great, save only with the king of Israel.

And it came to pass, when the captains of the chariots saw Jehoshaphat, that they said, It \add is\add* the king of Israel. Therefore they compassed about him to fight: but Jehoshaphat cried out, and the \sc Lord\sc* helped him; and God moved them \add to depart\add* from him.
For it came to pass, that when the captains of the chariots perceived that it was not the king of Israel, they turned back \add again\add* from pursuing him.

And a \add certain\add* man drew a bow at a venture, and smote the king of Israel between the joints of the harness: therefore he said to \add his\add* chariot man, Turn thine hand, that thou mayest carry me out of the host; for I am wounded.

And the battle increased that day: howbeit the king of Israel stayed \add himself\add* up in \add his\add* chariot against the Syrians until the even: and about the time of the sun going down he died.
